Calibration of the outside length is a calibration that most 3D printer owner perform. But calibration of the inside length / diameters is often forgotten.
That is why I made a simple calibration model to test both measurement in a fast way.

The Gcode is sliced with Simplify3D with the following settings:

Nozzle temp: 210
Bed temp: not set
Layer height: 0,20 mm
Infill: 15% fast honeycomp

Heated bed temp can be set manually.

The measurements of the calibration model are:
40 x 40 x 4 mm
1 hole of 10 mm
1 hole of 20 mm

title: Prusa Mod with steep-threaded spindles in x-y
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Originally it was a Prusa i3 from Geeetech.

At the moment it's more brainstorming!

How it began:
A capacitive sensor!
Then the GT2560 smoked away with 24V after 3 month. Then I used Ramps and changed the stepper motors!

I decided to make it to a test object for my next printer.

I bought a new frame from Capt Piquard.(http://www.thingiverse.com/Piquard/about)
He's a great guy, very friendly, fast, helpful and very fine working !
So we decided to make a new project, testing steep-threaded spindles in x and y in combination with igus parts.

Thanks to igus. They have a great support

State: still working

V1.

The RADDS 1.5 with RAPS128 has come. This combi is still printing all the parts used for this mod!

Nearly all the parts have been created in CAD (except the holder for the printer).

The frame is ready. The last parts came this morning!

(01.07.16) all the parts are here

all the parts have been printed We'll see

The new heatbed (completely. First come the other things)(Tiffany-style found at Dr-Henschke.de)

Mods in Y:

6.35mm 25.4mm/turn steep-threaded spindles with two taps (4mm) and a Zero-Backlash nut from igus

The side-bars have been stabilized with two rods every side, beneath the threated rod.
You can use older rods or cheap one for that! It prevents to much pressure through wrong fixing the threated rod.
You can use these rods to fix the printer, too! It's better than pressure on the threated rods
Replacing the motor outside the side-bar

The LM8UU in the bearing housings have been replaced with igus RJ4JP-01-08

The linear guides have been replaced by igus Drylin R EWM-08 -421mm

both side-bars contain a SKF 4x16mm bearing.

modified and self printed e-chain (two chambers for thermistor and heatbed).

min and max endstop

Mods in Z:

new developed carrier with the possibility to weight the ballance (lower backlash on the other side of the motor)

A second linear guide every side for more stabilization!

Threated rods (igus drylin) with 5mm taps and a SKF 5x16mm bearing in the top-holder.
Using igus dryspin lead screw nut with camber (DST-JFRM-LC-0001-TR8x1.5) for lower backlash

Mods in X:

6.35mm 25.4mm/turn steep-threaded spindles with two taps (4mm) and a Zero-Backlash nut from igus

The LM8UU in the bearing housings have been replaced with igus RJ4JP-01-08

The linear guides have been replaced by igus Drylin R EWM-08

both side-bars contain a SKF 4x16mm bearing.

The Extruder Carrier has been modified!

The Z- and Y- axis is working very fine.

The decay isn't corrected, the second extruder not correctly defined, the new printbed isn't ready, but the first prints are great, better than all the other before!
The fat Nozzles from mapa-refining are great!

V2:

The Display isn't working with RADDS.
Therefore I bought a Sparklab LCD with Adapter - it runs fine

Piquard has holidays.
He has the new print Bed for CNC workings
He makes the CNC things for my new developed quick change aluminium extruder carrier

All the printed (except the prusa holders) will be printed again with Bridge Nylon.
Most parts have been modified to get mor space for the x-axis, or for easier construction.

Hall-E-Endstops have been ordered - I got them
RADDS Expansion board has been ordered - I got it

Ordered 4 other stepper motors from nanotec.
ST4118L1804-A with 0.5 Nm for Z
ST4118D1804-A with 0.8 Nm for X/Y

Z is running fine, but a little bit slow, I hope the nanotec is a little bit faster (the motor holds 0.5Nm up to 300 turns/minute)

X/Y looses steps, beause the motors have not enough power to hold the point when the direction change after a travelling period
I'll change to E3D V6 Hotends. The Dual MK8 Extruders are too heavy. I demounted one and the prints don't loose steps. The prints are fine, but it's not fast enough
It looses steps, not as much as with two extuders, but when Vref is all right, the motors become too hot. If Vref is a little bit too low, the motor hasn't enough power!
Cooling the motors helps.
I ordered two mk8 heatsinks and two 30mm cooler for the x-y stepper motors!

The Raps 128 become very hot, too.
The RADDS housing will be recreated with 100mm cooler

I ask me, why some people say that they can print 300mm/s!
with a GT2 2mm Belt, 20-22 tooth -> 40-44mm/full turn.
A standard NEMA 17 from Asia makes not more than 100/120 turns/min (12V) -> 1.x-2 turns/s -> 70-88mm/s.
I don't say 300mm/s is not possible, but you need nearly 8 turns/s or 480 turns/m

I think about the Diamond Nozzle and a marzipan extruder for the quick change extruder carrier

If someone knows the parameters to print multicolor with RGB colors instead of CMY with the diamond nozzle, your welcome.
I want to use 5 Nozzles. the Diamond with RGB, one with black and one for PVA (e.g. Innosolve)

Update: 25.07.
The nanotec stepper motors works fine. I'll tell more about them, when Piquard has sent me the new CNC parts.

The height adjustable endstop holder for Hall-E are working fine.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1689289
(When minimizing the height, you have to change the height value in EEPROM and save it. Use a smaller value than the real one. After that you have set G29)

author: Sprenger

print_settings.Notes:: 30% infill reduces/absorbs a lot of the ricochet energy in case of a fork hit! If you have doubts about stability due to low infill or after a fork hit, put the slingshot on solid ground so that it forms a bridge and step on it. If it does not break from 60 up 90 kg its good for shooting. If you have really big hands, scale it up so that you feel comfortable with the grip.

title: Semi-Tube Slingshot for the right hand (left handed version)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE!

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1740720

Learn more about the story of the Semi-Tube Slingshot and its performance at www.slingshotforum.com. Search for 'aiping'!

Features

(draw right and hold left here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1589828)

Oval fork cones allow to attach flat bands up to 9 cm wide
(my favorite 9 cm / 3,5 cm / 25 cm TBB, with an active band length of 24 cm and a draw of 130 cm the draw weight is about 11 kg ...o.k ..band life time is than max 30 shots, depending to the weight of the ammo ...but two bands can simply be made from one strip TBB 12,5 x 26 cm, just cut diagonal from the two opposite 9 cm marks and than equalize the ends to a symmetric trapeze). Detailed procedure you can find here:

http://slingshotforum.com/topic/50425-semi-tube-slingshot-pouchband-attachment/

Tests with multilayer TBB (blue&black) showed that single layer TBS/TBG should be no problem.

Steel ball dispenser up to 13 mm, prepared to glue in a magnetic disk diameter 10 mm / hight 5 mm (my favorite 9,5 steel, no or mild hand-slap)
Tactical flashlight holder diameter 14 mm (don't use a laser for aiming !!!)
Tilted fork to support a straight fist
Warning! This slingshot is only for experienced shooters, draw at least 5 times effective
band length. You need speed to let the ball exit before the semi-tubes expand and block the trajectory.

Use of this slingshot at your own risk, especially full butterfly! No bands longer than 28 cm, taper at least 2:1.

LEGAL&SECURITY: Only print and use this slingshot according to the legal regulations of your country. NEVER EVER shoot at humans, even not point and aim. ALWAYS use protective glasses. I strongly suggest a catch box made at least from 15 mm plywood, 20 cm dense plastic foam or 1 mm steel. Don't shoot at concrete or brick walls due to violent ricochets, which can seriously injure yourself or bystanders, of course damage windows, flat screens etc. Only shoot as far as you are able to see, aim AND hit your target.

Band attachment: Bands should be at least 5 cm wide at the fork, wrap symmetrically from the upper oval tip, wider bands up to 9 cm until it touches the inner fork than utilize the outer fork . The flat-band should overlap the groove about 5 mm. To fix the flat band I use small office rubber which fits on the loop of my index finger/thumb, Don't cut the loop open. Wrap with strong force, so that office rubber color becomes pale, just before rupture. The bands don't snap off because the oval groove ensures an equal force distribution of the band fixing rubber and the fork cone also supports grip.

Slingshot orientation: Ball dispenser AWAY from your body, touching the inner index finger. The flat bands are directed from the grove to the end of the fork cones. This version is for hold right and draw left handed.

Printer:

daVinci 1.0

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3 ABS

Infill:

30% is enough for ME

Notes:

30% infill reduces/absorbs a lot of the ricochet energy in case of a fork hit! If you have doubts about stability due to low infill or after a fork hit, put the slingshot on solid ground so that it forms a bridge and step on it. If it does not break from 60 up 90 kg its good for shooting. If you have really big hands, scale it up so that you feel comfortable with the grip.

title: Shapeoko 3 Enclosure 25mm/1" Aluminum Extrusions with Drag Chain

description.text:
This is my enclosure for my new Shapeoko 3 desktop CNC. I'm sure it can be adapted for any CNC/3D Printer utilizing 25mm / 1" aluminum extrusions.

25mm/1" aluminum extrusions work perfectly with 1/4" plexiglass/lexan sheets, as it slides in perfectly between the middle lining/ridge, which is why I chose it instead of the more popular 8020/20mm extrusions. The 1/4" plexiglass was thought to be better for protection against possible flying debris (ie broken bits).

I printed all the corners/brackets instead of buying the metal ones because I was cheap - and I needed to put my two 3D printers to use. Plus it was fun to design!

Anyway, nearly everything is tapped for M5 screws. I used #6 screws for the door hinges, because I had a bunch laying around.

The back vacuum hose adapter is 52mm I believe, which fits my shopvac.

As for the drag chain, I chose the 15x30mm ones I found on Amazon for $13ish. These are the ones that is semi-opened so you can fit all the cables, and without snaking.

comments.text:
Caj,
PROGRESS! I took your advice and changed the parameters to .32 print thickness (that's the max the slicer recommends) raised the flow level to 100% and dropped print speed to 40. I reprinted both the key and the A3 latch, but laid the key flat on the bed with support to the baseplate. Put it back together with those new parts and even with the key's locator pin broken off in the main body, it worked!I've got a new main body printing out now with those same parameters. I didn't try the new nuts yet as the original ones have been on and off a few times and fit better now. I'll print out a set of the new ones to use on the new main body, though. Thanks for your help!
comments.author: MrBill72012

comments.text:
Caj,
First of all, I need to say that I've only been playing with this printer for a few months, so take the following with that in mind. I got all the parts for one cuff printed out and separated from the raft with no problem. All the pieces seemed to fit as designed given the inaccuracies of these printers when making close fitting parts. First problem I had was putting the nuts on. I tried to screw the first on on and it just sheared off the stud. The other three I pushed on and that worked better. I closed the cuff with a satisfying "click", and tried to open it with the safety button on the back. Snapped it right off. So I tried the key. Same results. I'm running a kit built HicTop Prusa Mendelson 3DP-11, Print thickness was 0.2, nozzle temp 210, bed temp 60. I used a solid fill, a raft, support everywhere (although the flag on the key was the only place that used any support), a print speed of 75, and a flow of 80%. I'm using Hatchbox silver PLA, 1.75mm. If you or any of your viewers see anything in my setup that I can change to improve the weak spots, I'd be happy to hear from y'all. Thanks for the files, the quick response on the missing piece, the new information I've picked up on this project, and the enjoyment of watching this thing print!

title: Shapeoko 3 Dust Shoe with LED ring

description.text:
After getting my Shapeoko 3, I learned the hard (messy) way what a dust shoe was and why you needed it. Looking around, I didn't find anything I like, not to mention NOT cover up the drill bit. Half the fun was watching this thing for hours and hours cutting millimeters of wood at a time. While this may not be as "efficient" at dust collecting as something with a brush that keeps the dust from flying everywhere, its "good enough", and I can still see whats going on. Besides, I have this nifty enclosure that keeps the dust under control for post-cut vacuuming.

Anyway, looking at some nice dust shoes for various CNC machines, I rolled this one. Even has a 60mm LED ring adaptor on the bottom to light up whats being cut (and sucked up the hole).

There are 5 pieces. The top 3 "plates" are screwed together with a long #6 screw (I had a bunch from Home Depot). The bottom cap is glued to the bottom plate. I did this as it was exponentially easier to print than having it as a single piece. The bottom LED ring can be screwed together with any short small self-tapping wood screw. I forgot which I use, but I had a bunch laying around.

The LED ring itself is just zippy tied to the adaptor (see pic).

author: jup2000

description.text: customized with 3D Slash!

Pinch roller lever for vinyl cutter plotter (Rabbit). These break very easily. This is a very close, but not exact copy of the original. This is from a China manufactured machine branded "Rabbit" and is possibly used on several plotters and printers.

Printed in PLA with supports. Some cleaning up required.
It's very simple to fit and it is not necessary to remove the carriage or rail from the machine, but for clarity:
Release the tension from the pinch pressure spring if it is not possible to use the broken lever
Remove the small screw in the top of the carriage adjacent to the spring
The (white) plastic dowel pin will push through the carriage. It is a very tight fit. Tools were needed.
The inside of hole in the new lever may require sanding smooth to allow free rotation round the dowel pin.
Ensure that the small intent in the outer circumference is clean
Note that this lever hole is approx 1mm wider than the width of the lever.
Re-assembly is the reverse. Note that the screw hole in the pin must align with the hole in the carriage.
Banana Jar to protect your bananas/scales on the go.

title: 2-Star Chicago Flag Coaster
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This beverage coaster design is inspired by the beautiful and well-known City of Chicago Flag.  The rounded-square coaster measures approx. 3 3/4" x 3 3/4" x 5/32" (95mm x 95mm x 4mm).  Works great for  almost any size beverage!

Option 1:
Print the file "Chicago_Flag_mm_base" in white.
Use paint (or maybe nail polish) to color in the recessed stars with red and the recessed stripes with blue. Option 2:
Print the file "Chicago_Flag_mm_base" in white.
Print 2 x "Chicago_Flag_mm_stripe" in blue and glue them into the recessed areas in the base.
Print 2 x "Chicago_Flag_mm_star" in red and glue them into the recessed areas in the base.
Repeat for as many coasters as you would like. Enjoy! Note: The stripes and stars may need to be slightly scaled down to fit into the base properly depending on your printer's calibration.

title: SCOUTcorexy XY_Stage XCarriage 8mm YCarriage 10mm HorizontalRods SingleHotend
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
NOTE: This version has a flaw, namely the airflow from the lateral axial fans doesn't reach the critical section of the hotend's heatsink, that is the first few fins closest to the heater block, unless you would design yourself a shroud that redirects the air to the lower fins. The 10mm designs overcome this flaw).

NOTE: I am working on the 10mm version of the SCOUTcorexy 3D printer XY stage (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1606042) and the features of the XCarriage that have been developed for that one are quite incompatible dimensionally with the 8mm version. I can provide that XCarriage here with LM8UU holes instead of LM10UU but everything else will remain the same.
Please follow the 10mm design, I will leave this here just for inspiration/reference.

I have started designing an XCarriage for Bowden setups and Horizontal Rods that overcomes most of the static and dynamic errors that affect printing during the accelerations/jerks/etc of a 3D printer (discussion here: http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?1,668254).

Here’s the Album with explanations added to each print screen where I am explaining the features of the design: https://is.gd/JQ5c0k

Sketchfab 3D model with exploded view here: https://sketchfab.com/models/4ed5cc9d9e7b48cf8f739fa350ba49e5/embed

DETAILS:

  • X uses 8mm rods and LM8UU bearings
  • Y uses 10mm rods and LM10UU bearings
  • belt is gt2
  • Hotend is a clone of E3Dv6
  • axial fans are 30mm
  • radial blowers are 4020 type
  • all in all the XCarriage is very symmetrical and any forces applied during accelerations, jerks, etc, are evenly distributed so that the nozzle remains as fixed as possible.
  • PRINTABLE Area:
    X -> 72% of YRod length (275mm for 350mm Rods)
    Y -> 78% of XRod length (275mm for 340mm Rods)
    Z -> 82% of ZRods length (270mm for 330mm Rods)

Features:

  • 60mm XCarriage (the Belt-Catchers go inside the YCarriages so they are not wasted space);
  • Belts go in straight line and in the same plane from YCarriages towards the XCarriage;
  • Belts can be tensioned with simple screws and dome-nuts pressing on the belt, forcing it into the niche designed for it; belts can be independently tensioned;
  • Hotend supported both upside carriage and lower side by the 4 screws;
  • Dual-30mm fans for coldend cooling;
  • Dual-30mmfan (or squirrelcage blowers) for part cooling [still very undecided here];
  • Hotend Mount is quite easily detachable by unscrewing the bolts that clamp the bearings, and another tool can be swapped pretty quickly;

TBD:
1) some way to remove wiggle/play from the linear bearings
2) design it for dual hotend
[...]

Cheers,
Flo.

description.text:
This is a derivation of the OpenSCAD project submitted by Matt Larson. This was a project done by a high school physics class investigating the factors that affect the power generated by a wind turbine. This was the first full class 3D printing project that I did.

I've made a couple very minor changes to the OpenSCAD file to make the variable names more intuitive to my students. I also added in some clarifying comments where I thought they would help and cleaned up some Depreciated code.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

0%

Notes:

You may need to add a raft for some designs to keep them from falling over. If your machine can do a brim this would also help.

We used 2 perimeters on our turbine blades.

Clean off the flat rectangle. We used a steady hand and razor blades. We found you had to shave the bottom corners of the base off to fit easily into the hubs. Be very careful as the turbine blades break easily. You could print with more perimeters to increase strength, but then you risk them being too heavy to get turning.

This was made in OpenSCAD from a design originally submitted by Matt Larson.

Each of my two physics classes picked two parameters to vary. We ended up with:

  • Length
  • Width
  • Angle – Which was really twist
  • “Fat Point” – Ratio of top length to bottom length

We created 5 different versions for each parameter. I let the students decide what they wanted to set the parameters to as long as the blade was not absurd.
NGSS

A few years ago I managed to find money to buy a Makerbot Replicator for my classroom. It really is like magic. We spent quite a bit of time printing out cool stuff from the Thingiverse and a few project enclosures for electronics projects. I’d been wanting to do a cool design project with my physics students, but never really knew what it should be. 3D design is not a skill in the wheelhouse of virtually any of my students (our CAD program died a few years ago). Then I discovered OpenSCAD. The beauty of OpenSCAD is that you can create or find a program that generates the 3D design. As with many programming languages variables are declared at the beginning of the program. These variables can be made easily identifiable. Students do not need any 3D design or programming skills. All they need to do is change the variables in order to change the underlying design. See my short video above for clarification. Objectives
  • Students will build a mathematical model of the effect changing a wind turbine parameter has on its output.
  • Students will analyze data and models created by other groups to make predictions.
    • Audience
  • This project was done with high school physics students at the end of the school year.
  • I believe this could also be done in a high school math class.
  • If the "mathematical model" was removed and students were only expect to look at graphs made by each group I believe this could be done in Middle School or even upper Elementary.
    • Subjects
  • High School Physics
  • High School Math
  • Computer Science
  • Upper Elementary or Middle School Science
    • Standards
  • NGSS Scientific and Engineering Practices
    • Developing and using models
    • Analyzing and interpreting data
    • Using mathematical and computational thinking
  • NGSS Crosscutting Concepts
    • Patterns - Analyzing data to determine rates of change. In this case, the constant rate of change in velocity and the varying rate of change in position.
    • Scale, proportion, and quantity
  • NGSS Core Ideas - Physical Sciences
    • PS2.A: Forces and Motion
    • PS3.A: Definitions of Energy
    • PS3.B: Conservation of Energy and Energy Transfer
    • PS3.C: Relationship Between Energy and Forces

• Introduce the project and show students OpenSCAD. Show them how to change the variables and render the model.
  • Allow students to play so they can determine what each variable does.
  • Have student groups each identify one factor to change, while holding others constant. Note, this might mean two variable must be changed. Changing the "bottom_height" without changing "top_height" would change the total blade length as well. Students might change the ratio of top and bottom heights but keep length constant.
  • Student groups share what they want to change with the class for discussion and input.
  • Students create 5 different states varying their factor of choice. See my picture above where the "fat point" (or ratio of top to bottom) is changed while all other factors were kept constant.
  • Print. It took my printer 3-4 hours to print a full set of blades, That is 3 each or your 5 different designs.
  • Clean and mount blades in the hubs.
  • Student groups test their blades
    8.1 Method One: Press fit the shaft of a small hobby motor into the hole on the hub. Attach the motor leads to a volt meter. Position 20 cm in front of a box fan set to high. Read voltage.
    8.2 Method Two: Mount blade on a straightened a paperclip. Position 20 cm in front of a box fan set to high. Use a Vernier or Pasco photogate to measure the spin rate.
  • Students create a graph for their data and fit an equation using the regression function on their calculators.
  • Students share data, graphs, and mathematical models with the class.
  • Student groups use all of the data to design the "optimal" wind turbine blade
  • Print and test final blades
    • Duration
  • Day one: Steps 1-5 above.
  • Print over night
  • Day two: Clean and mount blades (step 7). Takes longer than you think.
  • Day three: Steps 8-9
  • Day four: Steps 10-11
  • Print over night:
  • Day five: Test and crown the winner!

• Student Skills:
    Know how to make an x-y scatter plot
    Know how to use the regression function on their calculators
    Know how to analyze graph data
  • Stuff needed
    Box Fan
    Test Equipment (dc hobby motor+volt meter or photogate)
    Some way to mount. I used a ring stand and attachments found in chemistry room

I looked only at the finished, optimized blade design. Some students ignored the data and created a design based upon what they thought would make a good design. As you might guess, these did very poorly. The groups that did the best used all of the data collected and changed each of the variables. This became a great teachable moment.

comments.text: Hello, I understand you want to find how the shape of the blade affects the power generated by the wind turbine. Is that correct? I noticed that in one of the pictures you change where the thickest part of the blade is. The whole blade geometry is actually mathematically calculated. It turns out there is a certain angle and size of a selected airfoil at each point of the radius of the blade for a certain wind speed and rotation of the blade where the wind turbine will be the most effective. You should read a little bit of Blade element theory. I hope this helps to point you in the right direction. :)

description.text:
Dieser Wandhalter ermöglicht das aufgeräumte Unterbringen einer 2,5" SATA / NAS Platte hinter einer AVM Fritz!Box 7490 (oder Boxen gleicher Abmessung). Voraussetzung ist ein SATA-USB3.0-Adapter von Icy Box (IB-AC603a-U3).

Achtung! Diese Montagereihenfolge einhalten!
Der Wandhalter wird an den vorhanden Löchern statt der FB an die Wand geschraubt.
Wichtig Senkkopfschrauben verwenden!
Dann wird der SATA-USB Adapter seitlich eingeschoben. Anschließend kann die Festplatte von oben eingesteckt werden. Wer der Schwerkraft misstraut kann seitlich noch eine Verschraubung der Platte vornehmen.
Abschließend FB einhängen.

Das Kabel des Adapters ist ausreichend lang um den seitlichen USB-Anschluss der FB zu erreichen. (Nicht vergessen diesen Anschluss in der FB auf USB 3.0 zu konfigurieren)

Durch den Wandhalter hängt die FB nach der Montage ca. 15mm höher.

Neben der Festplatte ist ausreichend Stauraum für Kabelüberhang der sonstigen Verbindungskabel von/zur FB.

title: Electronics Shelf
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Electronics shelf quick info.

ElecShelf.stl or ElecShelfwGlasses.stl: Choose 1. Only 1 needed, 0.3mm Z, 25% Grid infill, support everywhere.

Support.stl: 1 needed, 0.3mm Z, 15% Rectilinear infill, support.

LgCommandStripMount.stl: 2 needed, 0.3mm Z, 35% Rectilinear infill, no support.

Also needed: 2 3M Command Adhesive Strips, Large.

Optional: Super glue or the like.

Electronics shelf full info.

This is a shelf I designed to hold a Kindle and reading glasses as a gift for my mom.
Of course it can be used to hold any small item(s).

The first photo shows it holding a kindle and my glasses.
In the second photo I have it holding a 10.1" tablet, Kindle and I put a small
smart phone on the glasses ledge just because it fit.
The red, white and blue shelf was printed using PLAs.
The other was printed with glow in the dark green PLA and red T-Glase.

Currently I have one next to my bed for my cell phone and glasses and
I have another that holds onto my cell phone during the day by the PC.
I gave one to a friend who is also using it as a bedside shelf and
my mom is using one to hold her Kindle and reading glasses.

Printing and assembling.

ElecShelf.stl and ElecShelfwGlasses.stl are the main body of the shelf,
one has the small ledge for glasses and one does not. I used MatterSlice in
MatterControl to slice it at 0.3mm Z Layers with 25% grid infill and the
"support everywhere" option checked, that allows the triangle notches to come
out nicely and after removing the support no other finishing work was needed
to get the other pieces to lock in.

Support.stl is the wedge shaped item that provides the main support for
the shelf. When assembling the support will stick out slightly past the shelf, this
is to compensate for the thickness that command strips add. The support I
sliced with Slic3r at 0.3mm Z Layers with a 15% rectilinear infill, supports needed.
The hole that goes through the support allows for a charging cable.

LgCommandStripMount.stl is the key to everything, for the shelf you will need
to print 2 of them. If possible print the flat side down so that it comes out as smooth
as possible, otherwise you may need to sand them smooth to allow the Command
adhesive strip to adhere properly. It is sized to use a Large 3M Command Adhesive
strip. Sliced mine with Slic3r with 0.3mm Z Layers and 35% rectilinear infill, no support needed.

After printing everything and removing support material from the shelf and support,
you simply slide the support into the back of the shelf then snap the Command strip
mounts into the matching triangular pattern on the back of the shelf. Super gluing
everything together is optional and you'll have to decide if you want to based on how
well your parts snap together and the weight you intend to keep on it.
Follow the directions on the package for attaching the command adhesive to the shelf
and then to the wall.

Designed with Autodesk Fusion 360.

Used Microsoft's 3D Builder to change orientation of STL files.

Sliced with MatterControl and Slic3r.

This repository includes a number of parts which are designed to improve the bracing of the Zonestar P802Q/P802QA 3D printer.

For latest parts and more details visit https://github.com/ioquatix/zonestar-p802q-bracing.

-== Read instructions for printing and installation! ==-  
This mount will fit a standard camera bolt and can be adjusted on both the X and Y planes.  It can also be adjusted on the Z plane using washers.  
It bolts firmly to the Ultimaker but works best on light webcams (such as the Logitech 920C).  
It can be secured to any of the three center frame bolt for maximum hold, or moved the the outside of the frame posts for another angle (nine possible mounting points in all).

-== Requirements ==-
You will need:
[ Center Frame Install ]
-- 1 x 16mm Bolts (Included in UM Spares)
-- 1 x 20mm Bolts (Included in UM Spares)
-- Optional Washer [ Corner Frame Install ]
-- 2 x 16mm Bolts (Included in UM Spares) -== Printing ==-
For the "Top" and the "Base" using these settings:
  • Required: Brim
  • Required: Support touching build plate.
  • Recommended: 220C @ 50mm/ps
  • Recommended: 0.2 Layer Height
  • Recommended: 30+ % Infil
    • -- The washers can be printed without brim or support. @@ If the brim starts to pull up at all in the first few layers, it will probably fail! Watch it closely. @@ -== Installation ==-
    !! DO NOT INSTALL OVER THE FRAME PEGS !!
  • The bolt holes should be just the right size to self tap, I recommend tapping each hole on both the top and bottom away from the machine to prevent damage.
  • Clean the camera rail thoroughly, it is designed to be a little tight.
  • If you are doing a center frame install, remove the 16mm bolt from the frame (don't loose the nut).
  • Pre-install the two 16mm bolts on the top facing down.
  • Loosely install your camera on the top bracket. You may need to use the printed washers on the top.
  • Hang the bracket on the machine and get your picture lined up.
  • Hold the bottom clip in place and bolt the top into it. This does NOT need to be very tight.
  • Check your angle again and tighten up your cameras bolt.
  • If the camera is USB, the cable should be able to thread through the openings in the bracket for cable management.

remixed_from.title: Printable SATA hot swap hard disk caddy

description.text:
I love the design that the original was and did not feel as though i wanted to change anything. When i tried to print one though, well, that was a different story altogether. The unit is to tall for the makerbot rep 2 to create in a fashion that will not take more support that the object itself. I know because I laid it flat and printed one. =( took a half hour to break all the supports out...... Well what to do...... I ran the supplied solidworks file through my version of solidworks and split the unit right down the middle so I could lay them flat on their side and only use 1/35th the supports.
I am using these in a stack formation of 5.
that is four for hard drives and one to run a usb 3.0 hub and a mini itx power supply.
I will be sanding down the cases and painting them some cool color and making a hard drive array.
I provided the stl's separate. This way you can decide if you want to print both sides at once or separate.

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hU-2Rbbev_8

Laser/torch pointer

This is a remotely controlled arduino robot created with 3D printed parts (and yes, some electronics). With only two servos, this robot is able to point any object in the X and Y axis. The amplitude of the movement can be configured via Arduino CODE. You can control its movements by sending commands through your Smartphone, Tablet or PC WIFI. Its maximum control range is 60 meters (not bad! and we have even controlled it from 100 meters away).

Assembly info here: http://jjrobots.com/remotely-controlled-laser-pointer/

This is a good way to get into the electronics+robotic world. The same electronics are used in the Iboardbot and the Brobot EVO:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1069256
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1590702
So, if you get tired of the torch pointer, create an AWESOME iBoarbot!

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.16

Infill:

35%

Notes:

No support needed.

List of materials:

THE COMPONENTS LIST:

  • An inexpensive laser/torch (like the one in the video)
  • The 3D printed parts (case + servo supports)
  • 2x SG90 SERVOS (they are quite standard, easy and inexpensive to get)
  • 12V power supply (actually, from 9 to 12 volts will work). A good option is a regular 9V battery
  • B-ROBOT electronic brain shield v3.0 + Arduino Leonardo (the same electronics you have already used in other jjRobots projects: Brobot and iBoardBot):

Everything can be bought here:

http://jjrobots.com/product/remotely-controlled-laser-pointer/

Assembly instructions:

http://jjrobots.com/remotely-controlled-laser-pointer/

Another JJrobots:

If you have created this torch pointer, you already have the electronics and some of the ancillary elements to create your B-robot EVO and a iBoardbot! (yes, we have used the same items to create them ;-D ).

Take a look to the B-robot EVO (The fastest self balancing robot created with a 3D printer)

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1069256

And to the iBoardbot! (an OPEN SOURCE internet remotely controlled drawing robot)

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1590702

all the JJrobots are OPEN and can be modified as much as you want!
CREATE DIFFERENT ROBOTS USING THE SAME ELECTRONICS AND ANCILLARY ELEMENTS WITH THE MOST AWESOME ROBOTICS KIT

This is a clip commonly used on motorbike fairings to stick together. They easily break and are kind of expensive to replace if you buy them at your bike dealer.

They are used with many Honda motorbikes and as far as I know also with Yamaha and some other brands, too. If your brand uses them, then write it in the comments and I'll add it here in the discription.

I would recommend to print it with a slightly flexible filiament so it doesn't break easily. You might want to use a smaller nosle, too, since it has some very thin lines and you probably want it to actually fit.

The Part is about 16mm long, 10,5mm wide and 7,9mm high.

The primary goal of this project was to see if a 3D printed cup could withstand the 97 Â° C hot coffee. And it did!  
PLease note that I did not actually drink out of the cup, i have no idea what's going on in there when the hot coffee and printed nylon come together, it simply does not feel safe (yet).  
This print was done in Taulman 3D Nylon 618.  
As always i have included an STL and a STEP file. TopSolid 7 sourcefile is also available.

description.text:
Benchy is a fantastic and fun torture test for 3D printing (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:763622); but he doesn't float!.

I have made a few accessories to add to Benchy that helps with buoyancy and plugs some holes. The result is a floating Benchy!.

The accesories are clip on bump tyres, port hole plugs and a hold cover.

These accessories work fine with Benchys that were printed in PLA at 15 and 20% infill; I haven't tested them on other materials or %infills so they either might not work or may need to be positioned differently.

He will not float on anything other than very still water as he still floats very low down in the water. You also need to be careful placing in the water. Also after time water does leak in so he does not float very long either but this is only intended as a bit of fun!.

As the Benchy license does not allow modifications - I have contacted the designers and they have given their approval to post these accessories. Many thanks to Creative Tools for their support.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print all the tyre parts and push fit or glue together the tyre and clip. All the parts are separate files for printing in different colours. The tyre insert is optional for either colour matching to the Benchy or to provide a better finish if your bridging is not great.

In the red Benchy in the photo I printed the hold plug from Bronzefill to allow more weight at the rear. He will still float with a normal PLA plug and the black Benchy has a PLA hold plug.

Only the hold plug really needs to be 100% infill; the tyres in the photo were printed at 0% infill for greater buoyancy but also work at 100%.

You might need to sand the port hole plugs a little to fit as these are intentionally very tight.

The heated bed is set to 65 degrees Celsius.

I sliced three versions:

  • 1 without auto bedleveling available & with heated bed
  • 1 without heated bed & without auto bedleveling available

  • 1 Starting with extruder 1, switching to extruder 2 and finishing with extruder 1

description.text:
About a year ago, I created a model road bike, that printed out in one sheet and snapped together. It's been pretty popular, so I thought it could use a companion for those of us who prefer to take their desk toys off-road. I hope you all enjoy it!

printing and assembling process is the same as the road bike, however due to the larger tires and frame this takes about twice as long (about 1hr on my printer, your mileage may vary). However, the fit of the parts should be better than before, and the parts are more detailed. Like the road bike, a knife is recommended to help separate the parts and clean them up, and a bit of superglue doesn't hurt.

If you want to display it more prominently, you should also print out my Snap-together model Bike Stand.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

I used a raft, but it's not necessary at all. I run the first layer slower to make sure all of the small parts are printed properly. careful not to break off/damage any parts when peeling it off the bed!

description.text:
Complex_numbers gives some basic functions for complex numbers in OpenSCAD. A complex number is a vector with two entries, the real and the imaginary part. There are functions for complex multiplication and division, complex conjugate and taking real powers of complex numbers.
Rotation_2_point_bar is a single module, it takes two vectors in 3 dimensional space as input and then draws a cylinder between them. This is useful for making grids or meshes. Once the vertices of the mesh are known, one can use this module to draw all the edges.
The main file is boys_surface_vertices which gives a rendering of Boy's surface using a simple square mesh.

description.text:
I have an Oculus Rift and I really don't like demoing it to friends whilst worrying if they are going to yank on the cable and pull my PC off the desk, so I threw together a 3d printed housing which combined with some good quality 1m cables works well as a breakout box.

I've attached the box to my desk either with strong velcro, so should the cable get a tug it should pull the connectors out of the box rather than the PC off the desk. The build works well enough that you can thread the cables in through the front and then just clip the back into place, you could use glue if you really wanted but it shouldn't be needed.

The box was made specifically for the 2 cables below but could be made to work with most USB & HDMI cables.

USB 3.0: https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B00C7S1B4W/
HDMI: https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B004VR9VXK/

description.text: Made obsolete by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2341 Use for separating cap from beer bottle (non-twistoff). Works on the same principle as banging the bottle against a counter. Does not require the addition of any other parts (such as a penny as Zach originally suggested). Next version will have the handle slot deleted/fixed since it does not print correctly. Currently is in beta state, has opened a bottle for me, but may not work for you. Please submit photos of the bottles it did not work on so I can improve the design. Current GCode file is for 4032D PLA, but may work for ABS. Its also raft-less since Ive found PLA prints better without one. Note: If you are making your own GCode for this, make sure you use at least 50% infill as anything less than that may make the part too weak to open the beer. So far I have been able to open 3 bottles with one made out of PLA before failure. Let me know how different materials fair for you.

• Print (GCode file takes ~20 minutes)
  • Wait for part to cool (2-5minutes). This is important since you need the full strength of the plastic
  • Open beer
    3A. Insert beer bottle into opener so the top of the opener is below the bottom of the cap. This will be somewhat hard to do as the tolerances are very close
    3B. Grab neck of beer bottle with hands, push upwards on the tab with your thumbs. Warning: cap/opener will come flying off.
    3C. Enjoy beer

title: Regular star polygons and star figures

description.text: Regular star polygons and star figures of arbitrary sizes, number of sides, skipped vertices per side and subfigures (for compound star figures). They came as OpenSCAD modules in three flavours: conventional, solid and contoured. These stars make a nice ornament and can be used as building blocks for other figures. This thing is similar to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5052 .

Download the OpenSCAD file stars.scad, read the comments and use the modules to make your own stars. There are three modules:
  • star: regular stars with all their sides
  • solid_star: solid, filled stars
  • contoured_star: the contour of a star
    • There are several options that can be passed as parameters:
  • radius: the radius of the star (i.e. the radius of the circumscribed circumference)
  • thickness: line thickness (for star and contoured_star)
  • height: the height of the figure
  • sides: number of sides of the star
  • skip: vertices to be skipped: sides connects every "skip"th vertex
  • figures: number of figures compounding the star. This is useful for making compound stars like the hexagram, which is made by two stars of an intended number of sides of six and a skip of two (i.e. two triangles)
    • If you don't know so much about regular star polygons but want to make stars, you can read the Wikipedia article http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_polygon to know the meaning of the different parameters of the modules. You could try to make some stars in glow-in-the-dark plastic.

title: Prusa Y Motor Mount - No Idler Needed!

description.text: I wasn't very happy with the standard Prusa Y motor mount due to it's lack of rigidity (I used a cable tie on the back of the motor for extra support until now.) Since I am running Synchromesh Cable now and not belts (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15923 ) and the cable is so thin I figured there was no need for an idler pulley above the motor. This eliminates one bearing and some nuts and washers and also helps your pulley get a better grip on the cable because it wraps 3/4 around rather than about 1/2 with the original motor mount.

Simply print, remove your old Y motor mount and the idler and put this one in it's place (it is a pain because you have to un-thread both front rods, but it is worth it for the improved quality.)  Enjoy the excellent pulley-to-cable connection!

author: Tuffdante

title: Ozobot Forklift
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a "forklift" attachment for an Ozobot. It should fit securely over an Ozobot with a skin. The forklift allows the Ozobot to push and/or guide objects to a destination. It will also allow you to complete construction activities available on the Ozobot Education website.

Update: I redesigned the forklift to fit easier about the Ozobot. The previous design was too tight. Young children often had problems attaching the forklift to the Ozobot. The new design is more flexible and grips the Ozobot with a protective skin. I also reduced the dimensions, which should improve printing times.

Update: I added a simple box which can be used with the Ozobot Construction challenge activities.

comments.text:
Le but de l'auteur n'est visiblement pas d'améliorer ton extrudeur techniquement mais e gommer un esthétique lui deplaisant.
Je parle en son nom sans savoir également je précise.
Maintenant si il a fait ça c'est visiblement pas que pour te faire chier. C'est dans le but d'avoir certainement un extrudeur sans inscription, et donc inéluctablement il l'a jugé intéressant pour perdre le temps de le faire et donc il compte le tester voir même l'adopter.
Enfin c'est ce que je pense.
Maintenant je n'ai pas connaissance des passifs et différends t'opposant aux autres printers et pour être honnête je m'en contrefou. Tout ce que je vois c'est que quelqu'un a gommé des détails esthétiques que sûrement certaines personnes aurait repoussé. Ça n'enlève rien à ton travail à toi et ton équipe de test. Maintenant qui? Pourquoi ? J'ai envie de dire on s'en fout, c'est le même en neutre pourquoi pas. description.text:
This is a 45mm extended version of the Ikea plinth clips. Photo shows the original on the left and the new one on the right.
http://www.ikea.com/gb/en/catalog/products/40205599/

I needed these to clear some larger bases required for washing machine / fridge. The Ikea system puts the plinth in quite far from the outer edge.

Its printed horizontally with only a few supports in key locations. The initial print was vertical however layer adhesion was an issue so was not strong enough.

IMPORTANT, add a small brim maybe 3 outlines, this stops the bottom of the rear plate slipping away, see slicer photos. You could add more supports for a cleaner print but I wasn't really worried about its appearance these clips are hidden anyway.

description.text:
Successful replications:
theEnoch (gpsmacy): https://youtu.be/OOG1NYHr4eI

History and Today:
The phenakistoscope (also spelled phenakistiscope or phenakitiscope) was an early animation device that used the Persistence of vision principle to create an illusion of motion. The Phenakistoscope is regarded as one of the first forms of moving media entertainment that paved the way for the future motion picture and film industry.

Although this principle had been recognized by the Greek mathematician Euclid and later in experiments by Newton, it was not until 1829 that this principle became firmly established by the Belgian Joseph Plateau.

The Special Honorary Joseph Plateau Award, a replica of Plateau's original phenakistiscope, is presented every year to a special guest of the Flanders International Film Festival whose achievements have earned a special and distinct place in the history of international film making.

Usage:
The user would spin the disc and look through the moving slits at the disc's reflection in a mirror. The scanning of the slits across the reflected images kept them from simply blurring together, so that the user would see a rapid succession of images that appeared to be a single moving picture.

Printing:
Using different colors for the top/middle/bottom discs is important or you will not notice the effect. The more different the colors the better.

description.text:
